My estimates come in at about $638 billion in 2033 just to make up  the shortfall of the Social Security trust fund being gone and the  Medicare trust fund being gone. That is, what, 60 percent of today's  defense budget.

Why is math such an anathema to this place?

Let's walk through a couple…

…less than 6\1/2\ to 7 years,  Medicare will go from $1 trillion to $2 trillion. Also, in 7 years,  Medicare is gone.

Excuse me. Let me rephrase that. The Medicare trust fund is gone, and  that will result in around an 11 percent cut, particularly to  hospitals.

It is demographics. Baby boomers are moving into their peak  utilization years of these…

Don't tell  anyone that the Medicare trust fund is gone in 7 years and that their  hospital is probably going bankrupt.…

…between, in 7 years, the $1  trillion we spend this year on Medicare becomes $2 trillion. We double  the spend on Medicare in the next 7 years, and in 7 years, the trust  fund is gone, meaning if you are a hospital or a doctor and part of  your revenues that you receive on Medicare patients is from the  Medicare Part A trust fund, it is gone. It is gone…

…The baby boomers have moved into their retirement  years. We have a societal promise we have to keep. We made a promise,  but once again, in 7 years, the Medicare trust fund is gone. Remember, in 2033, about halfway through the year, the trust fund is  gone. Is that a Republican or a Democratic problem? I would say it is a  morality problem. We will be doubling senior poverty in America in 8  years.

Remember, our math from last year is the first full year with the  Social Security trust fund gone. Just the shortfall is over $600  billion. The scale of what we are talking about is brutal.

Mr. Speaker, you intend to be here for another decade, so you are  going to…

…willing to have a conversation of how we are  going to save it?
